thread.title: At least 3 victims of small plane crash in Australia ID’d as Texans
thread.title_full: At least 3 victims of small plane crash in Australia ID’d as Texans

author: Liz Farmer
title: At least 3 victims of small plane crash in Australia ID’d as Texans
text:
Get Unlimited Digital Access Your first month is less than a dollar. $0.99 for first 4 weeks Subscribe Now 
At least three of four U.S. golfing tourists killed in a small plane crash in Australia Tuesday have been identified as Texans by their families. Four American tourists on a dream vacation were killed overnight when their small plane slammed into an Australian shopping center. pic.twitter.com/aJjGpO4lGC — CBS This Morning (@CBSThisMorning) February 21, 2017 
A total of four people and the pilot died when the twin-engine Beechcraft Super King Air crashed into a shopping mall in Melbourne shortly after takeoff, officials said. 
The plane exploded on impact and erupted into a "massive fireball," witnesses told NBC News. The crash occurred about an hour before the mall was supposed to open, police said. 
The families of Texans Greg Reynolds De Haven and attorney Russell Munsch identified them on social media. 
De Haven's sister Denelle Wicht posted on Facebook that her 70-year-old brother, a retired FBI agent, had been killed "on a once in a lifetime trip to Australia" with friends, The Herald Sun of Melbourne reports . (Facebook) 
Austin-based entrepreneur and investor Glenn Garland also died in the crash, The Sun reports . Breaking: Third US victim of Essendon plane crash named as Glenn Garland https://t.co/icAULYpPhd — Paul Tatnell (@PaulTatnell) February 21, 2017 
The tourists were headed to a golfing vacation on King Island, about 160 miles south of Melbourne. 
Max Quartermain, the pilot and owner of the charter company Corporate and Leisure Travel, reported a "catastrophic engine failure" just before the plane crashed into a storage area at the back of the mall, police said. — damon johnston (@damonheraldsun) February 21, 2017 
The Associated Press contributed to this report. View Comments
